awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of A Novel Instrument that Minimizes Uncertainties in Airborne Measurements of Precipitation
awd_abstract_narration:
Weather radar, satellites, and numerical models all require accurate knowledge of the properties of cloud and precipitation particles.  The atmospheric science field has spent decades conducting airborne field measurement campaigns with the goal of collecting as much data as possible to characterize the distribution of droplet and crystal sizes and shapes.  However, fundamental limitations of aircraft probes have left many unanswered questions and uncertainties.  This award is for the development of a new airborne probe that will enhance the observational research community's efforts to characterize cloud and precipitation particles.  The potential societal impacts of this award will be through more accurate precipitation measurements from radar and satellites, and improvements in inputs to weather and climate models.   

This Major Research Instrumentation development award is for the design and construction of the fourth generation High Volume Precipitation Spectrometer (HVPS-4) for measurement of cloud and precipitation particles.  The HVPS-4 will provide orthogonal digital images of cloud and precipitation particles at 50 and 150-micron pixel resolution.  The orthogonal views will reduce uncertainties in particle shape, aspect ratio, volume, and mass.  The HVPS-4 could be mounted on the NCAR G-V and C-130 research aircraft, or other aircraft that regularly carry particle probes. The instrument has the potential to: 1) Lead to better understanding of cloud microphysical processes and improved estimates of ice and liquid water content in clouds and precipitation, 2) Improve remote retrievals from ground and space-based radar, and 3) Improve microphysical and hydrological parameterizations in weather and climate models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit of the Research

A new airborne instrument, the High-Volume Precipitation Spectrometer (HVPS-4) was designed, fabricated and flight-tested as a result of the funded research. The HVPS-4 has four channels, two orthogonal (horizontal and vertical) views that each have 50- and 150-?m pixel resolution, providing improved measurements of the aspect ratio of falling raindrops, hail and snowflakes, which improves evaluation of polarized radar retrievals of cloud particle type (heavy rain, graupel, snow, sleet) and radar retrieval algorithms (of ice water content, snow rate).  In addition to the instrument design and fabrication, new software was developed to analyze particle images generated by the HVPS-4. 

Several flight tests were conducted using the SPEC Inc. Learjet in the vicinity of Boulder, Colorado. The flight tests confirmed that all four channels properly recorded images of ice crystals and water drops. SPEC was funded by the NSF through the State University of New York (SUNY) to operate its Learjet research aircraft in the ESCAPE (Experiment of Sea Breeze Convection, Aerosols, Precipitation, and Environment) field campaign staged from Houston, Texas during the month of June, 2022. The Learjet flew 11 research flights totaling 40 hours. Data were collected by the HVPS-4 and other in situ instruments in rain shafts and mixed-phase clouds with graupel particles (small hail) and ice crystals. 

 Broader Impacts of the Research

The HVPS-4 reduces uncertainties in retrievals of precipitation and hydrology from ground-based and satellite-borne sensors, improves parameterizations in climate prediction models, and has provided opportunities for students and post-docs pursuing careers in atmospheric science. The improvement in determination of precipitation particle shape and increased sample volume that reduces uncertainties in remote retrievals contributes to better forecasts of extreme weather events that affect numerous regions globally.  This provides improvement in parameterizations of climate models that are essential for aiding political strategies of climate change. 

NCAR has a long history of promoting and including students and post-docs in airborne field programs, which provides invaluable experience for the next generation of scientists. This project extended this outreach by allowing students to participate in the ESCAPE field project. HVPS-4 probes were installed on both the SPEC Inc. Learjet and Canadian National Research Council Convair 580 research aircraft.  Graduate students and post-docs from the University of Oklahoma, Stoney Brook and Michigan Tech participated in the ESCAPE field project and were trained on the HVPS-4 and data analysis.  A paper describing the HVPS-4 was presented at the 2022 annual meeting of the American Meteorological Society (AMS), and some results from the ESCAPE field project will be presented at the 2023 AMS annual meeting.
